Common Cold.description: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. It's usually harmless, although it might not feel that way. Many types of viruses can cause a common cold.
symptoms: Slight body aches or a mild headache
prevention: Don't share drinking glasses or utensils
Take care of your general health
prevention_tips: Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands
Stay at home when you are sick to prevent spreading illness to others
Practice good respiratory hygiene (cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue)
Strengthen your immune system through regular physical activity
lifestyle_recommendations: Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids like water, herbal teas, and clear broths
Get adequate sleep (7-9 hours) to help your immune system fight infections
Consume foods rich in vitamin C like citrus fruits, strawberries, and bell peppers
Use a humidifier to add moisture to the air and help ease congestion
Gargle with salt water to soothe a sore throat and reduce inflammation
Consider taking zinc lozenges within 24 hours of symptoms to reduce duration
Eat a balanced diet with plenty of fruits and vegetables to support immune function
treatments: Pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen

Influenza.description: The flu is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses that infect the nose, throat, and sometimes the lungs. It can cause mild to severe illness, and at times can lead to death.
symptoms: Vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children)
prevention: Get the flu vaccine each year
Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing
Avoid close contact with sick people
Stay home when you are sick
prevention_tips: Get vaccinated annually with the seasonal flu vaccine (ideally before flu season begins)
Practice good hand hygiene by washing hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
Use alcohol-based hand sanitizers when soap and water are not available
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands
Maintain at least 1-meter distance from people who are coughing or showing symptoms
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces at home, work, or school
If you're at high risk (elderly, pregnant, or immunocompromised), consider wearing a mask in crowded places during flu season
lifestyle_recommendations: Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of clear fluids like water, herbal teas, and broths
Get adequate rest and sleep to support your immune system (7-9 hours per night)
Maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits and vegetables to ensure adequate vitamin and mineral intake
Consider foods high in vitamin C (citrus fruits, bell peppers) and vitamin E (nuts, seeds) to support immune function
Engage in moderate regular exercise to boost immunity (30 minutes most days of the week)
Manage stress through meditation, yoga, or other relaxation techniques
If you smoke, consider quitting as smoking increases risk of serious flu complications
Limit alcohol consumption as it may weaken your immune response
treatments: Decongestants and antihistamines for symptom relief

Pneumonia.description: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs. The air sacs may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing.
symptoms: Chest pain when breathing or coughing
Confusion or changes in mental awareness (in adults age 65 and older)
Lower than normal body temperature (in adults older than age 65 and people with weak immune systems)
prevention: Be aware of your risk factors

Hypertension.description: High blood pressure is a common condition in which the long-term force of the blood against your artery walls is high enough that it may eventually cause health problems, such as heart disease.
symptoms: Most people with high blood pressure have no signs or symptoms, even if blood pressure readings reach dangerously high levels

Some people with high blood pressure may have headaches, shortness of breath or nosebleeds, but these signs and symptoms aren't specific and usually don't occur until high blood pressure has reached a severe or life-threatening stage
causes: Secondary hypertension (caused by an underlying condition)
Certain medications (birth control pills, cold remedies, decongestants, over-the-counter pain relievers and some prescription drugs)
prevention: Eat a healthy diet (low sodium, high in fruits and vegetables)

Diabetes.description: Diabetes is a disease that occurs when your blood glucose, also called blood sugar, is too high. Blood glucose is your main source of energy and comes from the food you eat. Insulin, a hormone made by the pancreas, helps glucose get into your cells to be used for energy.
symptoms: Presence of ketones in the urine (ketones are a byproduct of the breakdown of muscle and fat that happens when there's not enough available insulin)
causes: Type 1 diabetes: The immune system attacks and destroys cells in the pancreas that make insulin
Type 2 diabetes: Cells become resistant to the action of insulin, and the pancreas is unable to make enough insulin to overcome this resistance
Gestational diabetes: Hormones produced by the placenta during pregnancy can cause insulin resistance
treatments: Type 1 diabetes: Insulin therapy, carbohydrate counting, frequent blood sugar monitoring
Type 2 diabetes: Healthy eating, regular exercise, blood sugar monitoring, diabetes medication or insulin therapy
Gestational diabetes: Monitoring blood sugar, healthy diet, exercise, and sometimes insulin or oral medications

COVID-19.description: COVID-19 is a respiratory disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. It can cause a range of symptoms, from mild illness to pneumonia. Some people recover easily, while others may get very sick very quickly.
symptoms: Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
New loss of taste or smell
prevention: Wear a mask in public settings
Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated spaces
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily
prevention_tips: Stay up-to-date with COVID-19 vaccines and boosters as recommended
Wear high-quality masks (N95, KN95, or surgical) in crowded indoor settings
Maintain 2 meters (6 feet) distance from others, especially those who are sick
Wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in public
Use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol when soap is not available
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands
Improve ventilation in indoor spaces (open windows, use air purifiers)
Get tested if you have symptoms or have been exposed to someone with COVID-19
Follow local public health guidelines and stay informed about community transmission levels
lifestyle_recommendations: Maintain a strong immune system through regular exercise (at least 150 minutes of moderate activity per week)
Ensure adequate vitamin D levels through safe sun exposure or supplements if recommended by healthcare provider
Consume a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and foods high in vitamin C and zinc
Stay well-hydrated with water throughout the day
Get 7-9 hours of quality sleep each night to support immune function
Manage stress through mindfulness, meditation, or other relaxation techniques
Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking, as both can impair immune function
Monitor your blood oxygen levels if you have symptoms (pulse oximeter can be helpful)
Have a COVID-19 plan ready: know how to isolate, who to contact, and have essential supplies on hand
treatments: Antiviral medications (for those at higher risk)

Asthma.description: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, a whistling sound (wheezing) when you breathe out and shortness of breath.
symptoms: Wheezing when exhaling, which is a common sign of asthma in children
Trouble sleeping caused by shortness of breath, coughing or wheezing
Coughing or wheezing attacks that are worsened by a respiratory virus, such as a cold or the flu
causes: Airborne allergens, such as pollen, dust mites, mold spores, pet dander or particles of cockroach waste
Respiratory infections, such as the common cold
Air pollutants and irritants, such as smoke
Certain medications, including beta blockers, aspirin, and NSAIDs
Sulfites and preservatives added to some foods and beverages
prevention: Get vaccinated for influenza and pneumonia
treatments: Treat allergies if they trigger asthma symptoms

Migraine.description: A migraine is a headache that can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound.
symptoms: Prodrome: Constipation, mood changes, food cravings, neck stiffness, increased thirst, frequent yawning
Aura: Visual phenomena, vision loss, pins and needles sensations in an arm or leg, weakness or numbness in the face or one side of the body, difficulty speaking
Attack: Pain usually on one side of your head, but often on both sides, pain that throbs or pulses, sensitivity to light, sound, and sometimes smell and touch, nausea and vomiting
Post-drome: Feeling drained, confused and washed out, elated and energetic
causes: Drinks (alcohol, especially wine, and too much caffeine)
Sensory stimuli (bright lights, sun glare, loud sounds, strong smells)
Physical factors (intense physical exertion, sexual activity)
Foods (aged cheeses, salty and processed foods, food additives)

Arthritis.description: Arthritis is inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain and stiffness that can worsen with age. The main symptoms of arthritis are joint pain and stiffness, which typically worsen with age.
causes: Osteoarthritis: Wear and tear damage to joint cartilage
Rheumatoid arthritis: Immune system attacks the lining of the joint capsule
Gout: Uric acid crystals build up in joints
Infectious arthritis: Infection in the joint
Psoriatic arthritis: Associated with the skin condition psoriasis
treatments: Medications to reduce pain and inflammation

Bronchitis.description: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the lining of your bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from your lungs. People with bronchitis often cough up thickened mucus, which can be discolored.
causes: Workplace exposure to dust or fumes
prevention: Get vaccinated against flu and pneumonia
Wear a surgical mask around irritants
prevention_tips: Practice good hand hygiene to prevent viral infections
Avoid close contact with people who have respiratory infections
Stay up to date with recommended vaccinations
Use protective equipment when exposed to workplace irritants
Maintain good indoor air quality
Stay hydrated to help keep airways clear
Exercise regularly to strengthen respiratory system
lifestyle_recommendations: Quit smoking and avoid secondhand smoke
Use a humidifier to moisten air in your home
Practice breathing exercises to strengthen lungs
Get adequate rest during recovery
Stay hydrated with warm liquids
Avoid exposure to air pollution and irritants
Maintain a healthy diet rich in antioxidants
treatments: Antibiotics (only if bacterial infection is present)

Dengue Fever.description: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection causing severe flu-like illness and, sometimes causing a potentially lethal complication called severe dengue.
causes: Dengue virus (DENV) transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes
prevention_tips: Apply mosquito repellent containing DEET
Wear protective clothing (long sleeves and pants)
Use air conditioning or window/door screens
Empty standing water from containers around home
Stay in well-screened or air-conditioned areas
Be extra careful during dawn and dusk when mosquitoes are most active
Maintain clean surroundings to prevent mosquito breeding
lifestyle_recommendations: Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids
Get plenty of rest during recovery
Eat nutritious foods to support immune system
Avoid aspirin and NSAIDs due to bleeding risk
Monitor temperature and symptoms regularly
Keep surroundings clean and free of mosquito breeding sites
Follow up with healthcare provider as recommended

Malaria.description: Malaria is a disease caused by a parasite that spreads to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes. Symptoms usually begin within a few weeks after being bitten by an infected mosquito.
causes: Bite from a female Anopheles mosquito that has been infected by a Plasmodium parasite
prevention: Take preventive medicine if traveling to endemic areas
treatments: IV fluids and blood transfusions in severe cases

Tuberculosis.description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs. The bacteria that cause TB are spread from person to person through tiny droplets released into the air via coughs and sneezes.
symptoms: Coughing for three or more weeks
prevention_tips: Get vaccinated with BCG if recommended
Complete all prescribed medications if infected
Cover mouth when coughing or sneezing
Ensure good ventilation in living spaces
Get regular health check-ups if at risk
Maintain a strong immune system
Avoid close contact with infected individuals
lifestyle_recommendations: Maintain good nutrition with protein-rich foods
Get adequate rest and sleep
Stop smoking and avoid alcohol
Exercise regularly as tolerated
Keep all medical appointments
Take medications exactly as prescribed
Maintain good personal hygiene
